content.body: Hixie: about http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9198
since hspace and vspace are already now allowed on embed, I assume that bug must be asking that they be explicitly listed in the obsolete-and-nonconforming section
wonders what the chart on http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2010/03/05/ie8-smartscreen-filter-protecting-users-at-internet-scale.aspx shows
Hixie: "mean block rate for socially engineered software"
s/software/malware/
(in the full PDF report that's linked to there)
It might help if they actually used something closer to commonly used terms
since as far as I can see it appears to be comparing the anti-phishing mechanisms that various browsers provide
and what do the percentages mean?
number of attacks captured?
nessy: yeah, seems so
they should compare the absolute number of attacks that succeeded, that would be more interesting :)
I've seen the similar study published before and it seemed questionable to me
1) they don't give enough information to reproduce their results (neither original data, nor enough detail of the methodology)

2) what they do say sounded like there was a lot of arbitrary fiddling with the original test sites (e.g. to remove ones that exploit security bugs in some way other than social engineering, which seems pretty point-missing)
3) it's not clear if their data source for what sites contain malware in the first place is independent from Microsoft's
I would also say it's very suspicious that Firefox, Safari and Chrome get such different results, considering they all use Google's malware/phishing data
othermaciej: hmm, updated my Webkit and now I get "Nightly builds of WebKit are not supported on Mac OS X 10.5 at this time"
MikeSmith: that's a surprise to me
MikeSmith: it's also a surprise to the guy who makes the nightlies, so it's probably a bug
ah, OK
MikeSmith: does it work if you relaunch it?
I'm told that alert sometimes pops up incorrectly
doesn't work even if I relaunch it
I tried a few times now
fwiw, Get Info shows r55610
othermaciej: btw, can you advise me on how best to proceed with discussion about getting the author view of the HTML5 spec published as a WD?
Hixie: btw, are you supportive of publishing the static author view of the spec as a WD?
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec-author-view/
MikeSmith: if the editor proposes it, then the chairs would likely put an FPWD resolution before the group
I believe it meets the threshold of being a bona fide collaborative product of the WG
and I believe it is reasonably in scope
OK, thanks
so I guess will propose to Hixie that he propose it
I did notice that the author view radio button is now available on the TR page
yeah
let's please not make a lot of noise about that
MikeSmith: btw, my preference would be to start the publication cycle about 2 months from now
no one has ever explicitly told me that we can't have JS in docs in TR
it took about 1 month from the time the publication CfC was posted to the time we published
othermaciej: works for me
so we have to start the CfC in 2 months to actually satisfy the heartbeat requirement
yeah
if there were additional drafts ready by then, that would be cool
also if we publish WDs more often then hopefully it can be less dramatic
yes
so that means restarting WD discussion in early May, publishing in June
it would good to get new drafts out before the July/August holiday period
when a lot of people tend to be away for weeks at a time
MikeSmith: i'm happy for it to be there, though i think if we publish it we should probably do it as a subcomponent of the HTML5 spec, not a separate /TR/ deliverable
MikeSmith: probably should make it clear that it's non-normative, too
Hixie: how would you do it as a subcomponent? separate link in the table of contents?
MikeSmith: bdash suggests "download a fresh build from nightly.webkit.org, and to save the bad build and file a bug report with it"
yeah, i guess
well, no
more like the same way we do the multipage version
there's a w3c convention for this kind of thing
links to pdf versions, multipage versions, etc
ah yeah
good point
we can just treat it as a variant of the full spec
ah, alternate non-normative formats
MikeSmith: re: http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec-author-view/ what’s up with the double asterisk overlapping “call” in “Status: last call for comments”
eg http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec-author-view/sections.html#the-article-element
looks like generated content, but I can’t see from where
boblet: no idea
some borkedness in the CSS stylesheet I'll need to unwind
heh
boblet: what browser?
othermaciej: OK, grabbed a fresh build and it's working fine
MikeSmith: woot
othermaciej: so what should I attache to the bug report?
zip up the WebKit.app ?
Hixie: seeing those asterisks in Chrome and FF latest for Mac. Only me?
boblet: does it disappear if you hit command++/command+- ?
nope. changing body font to serif changes position slightly though
(moves it to end of “call”)
holler if you want screenshots
boblet: sounds like a browser bug to me -- misplaced ::before or ::after from a class="XXX" element.
odd that it doesn't move when you resize though
.XXX:before, .XXX:after { content: " ** "; position: absolute; left: 0; width: 8em; text-align: right; }
MikeSmith: there you go. Pity inspector & Firebug don’t show generated content (& make it hard to access eg hover state CSS)
indeed
anyway, I just checked in a fiew
fix
eagle eye
happy to help ;-)
thinks boblet must read through specs with a jeweler's loupe
“hey, designers *are* good for something!”
heh
MikeSmith: what was the bug? (what did you change?)
Hixie: I made a copy of the http://www.whatwg.org/style/specification stylesheet
and have I that document referencing it
I can't quite remember why, now
but that's what it's doing
and what I did was just to comment out that part
.XXX:before, .XXX:after { content: " ** "; position: absolute; left: 0; width: 8em; text-align: right; }
neither of those should be necessary :-)
maybe someone who really really liked Markdown wrote the CSS?
I blame the CSS gremlins
boblet: i wrote that css, but it shouldn't be doing what you describe
boblet: hence why i think it's a browser bug
is there any input which can represent a time including seconds?
Hixie: what was the effect you wanted? It seems like it’s putting ** 8em from the left inside .XXX, and that happens to be about where class is
Creap: "A time consists of a specific time with no time-zone information, consisting of an hour, a minute, a second, and a fraction of a second."
Creap: from the spec on <input type=time>
ok, I was confused by http://www.w3.org/TR/html-markup/input.time.html#input.time + Opera's implementation lacking seconds
boblet: oh, i thought you meant it was nowhere near anything that should have had the stars
Creap: make sure to set step=1
boblet: it's supposed to attract attention to the issues
Hixie: the ** appear inside a paragraph with .XXX, so it’s as expected
boblet: ah ok
ah.
Creap: could you file a bug about opera's impl?
should it include seconds by default? using step=1 as hixie suggested makes it show seconds
Hixie: if you were wanting ** before and after, I think you might need to define :before and :after separately
do i have to use .closePath? or not?
boblet: why?
Creap: step=60 is the default, so it hides seconds by default
ok
is datetime's step also specified in seconds?
iirc, yes
ok i'm outta here. g'night all.
おつかれ
Creap: step="any" should make it show seconds
wonders if there's a dev.opera.com article on forms features
http://dev.opera.com/articles/view/improve-your-forms-using-html5/
hmm
it'd be nice with an article with more coverage
yeah
http://dev.opera.com/articles/tags/forms/ :(
hmm, we are really going to need some how-to guides about the new input types and other forms features
this stuff is not especially intuitive
http://www.w3.org/People/Jaffe/
yeh, new ceo eh annevk?
and his first post: http://www.w3.org/QA/2010/03/w3c_ceo_blog_first_posting_mar.html
does ie8 smartscreen differ from the phishing and malware blacklist features of other browsers in terms of features? or is the difference microsoft's server side instead of google's?
they have some purely client-side heuristics too, I believe
othermaciej: what time zone are you in? o_O
"other"
heh, ah yes, that one, i know it well.
(it's awkward living in EST, and working w/ people in GMT and PST)
http://www.w3.org/WAI/PF/src/role-attribute-src.html
the examples in that document seem somewhat misguided
does Webkit already have some mechanism for exposing orientiation/acceleromerter events to Web applications?
was reading the new Orientation Event spec http://dev.w3.org/geo/api/spec-source-orientation.html
and noticed that it informatively references https://developer.mozilla.org/en/XPCOM_Interface_Reference/nsIDOMOrientationEvent
and I remember recently seeing a guy do a File API demo in Mozilla that appeared to be reacting to changes in orientation of his Macbook
hah, that's cool :D
cool also to see that work seems to have started on implemented CSS3 Paged Media in Webkit - https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=15548
hsivonen: "but it looks like once it reads a conditional comment, it's too late to change X-UA-Compatible." -- http://www.sitepoint.com/forums/showthread.php?t=663679
zcorpan: Yeah, I'm aware that conditional comments (like scripts) make later X-UA-Compatible ineffective. I just haven't gotten around to updating the flowchart.
ok
mmm
So why doesn't HTML 5 include ruby markup in the spec? :)  (per Ishida's email on www-int)
it doesn't?
Hmm, apparently not
It does http://www.whatwg.org/html5#the-ruby
hmmm
yeah, just looking at that
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-international/2010JanMar/0107.html seems Richard is asking about complex ruby
which was deliberately left out
annevk: there's complex?
thought there was only 1 Ruby spec
see http://www.w3.org/TR/2001/REC-ruby-20010531/#complex
asmodai, well yeah, but nobody implements /TR/ruby/
Mmm, have never seen the complex case being used for Asian languages.
annevk: Aside from the addon for Firefox?
annevk: XHTML Ruby
asmodai, I doubt that plugin implements it correctly
but yeah
annevk: Actually, it passes all tests IIRC
annevk: http://www.w3.org/International/tests/results/results-ruby-markup-2
bit older version of the addon
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-international/2010JanMar/0107.html
asmodai, if it was done correctly it would've made it into Gecko by now
annevk, asmodai: addons don't go deep into layout and add CSS box types. proper Ruby support needs support from the CSS formatter, IIRC.
hsivonen, right
hsivonen: I know nothing of that. :)
did anything come of using @datetime on <article>? I’m guessing better to not have as an invisible attribute, but…
hsivonen: So I'll take your word for it.
huh. datetime isn’t mentioned under the-article-element and isn’t in global attribs, so I guess no
boblet: I seem to remember it being there for a while, then being removed
but I may have imagined it all
I definitely remember it being discussed for blog posts, but yeah not there now
I thought it was called pubdate now
is the following sentence in the book 'div into html5' (http://diveintohtml5.org/) book really true:
...The HTTP header is the preferred method, and it overrides the <meta> tag if present....
you can find it in this page: http://diveintohtml5.org/semantics.html#encoding
I thought the reason why the <meta charset=...> tag is available is because most authores CANNOT set the http content-type header
but when the http content-type header, which could be wrong', overwrites any authors attempt to alter the charset, the <meta charset=...> wouldn't make sense
Philip`: aah nice, thanks
I think this must be a typo in the book. can someone confirm this?
mr_danie1: I was under the impression that http header > meta charset
mr_danie1: I think the book is correct
http header outranks the meta charset
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/parsing.html#determining-the-character-encoding
mr_danie1: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-validator/2008Mar/0024.html
heh
"1. If the transport layer specifies an encoding, and it is supported, return that encoding with the confidence certain, and abort these steps."
(where HTTP is a transport layer, and specifies encodings via Content-Type)
mr_danie1: in the case where the server is serving data that it doesn't know the content type for, it should omit the content-type header completely I believe
rather than send a false type that will be taken as exact
I think  meta charset > http header would be better, for example: the server sets content-type:charset=utf-8, but the author sets <meta charset=iso-...
and when the http header, the content will be displayed wrong, because the content is iso-...
...http header WIN, the...
mr_danie1: Can't do that because it would be incompatible with all current browsers
mr_danie1: if the server is sending an incorrect content type, the server has a bug
and probably incompatible with lots of current pages
or is configured incorrectly... either way, it's not a problem with the standard
You should always use UTF-8 anyway :-)
ok, so html5 must use this policy because of its 'incremental html improvement' approach not to break the current web
workmad3: true, then the server has a problem
also, I believe in a lot of cases, it's the <meta charset= that is incorrect, because it was set on old content that has since been re-encoded
Philip`: true, utf-8 is my favourite; it hate encoding issues, especially when I work in a team with lot of people
mr_danie1: Yes, and also because it's probably better for the server to be authoritative
and (checking the wiki page on http encodings) it looks like <meta> content types should be used by the server, not the browser

You already have to trust the server to tell you the content is text/html rather than image/png or whatever, so it'd be odd if you trusted it to say the "content-type: text/html" part but not the "; charset=utf-8" part
workmad3: ?
Servers shouldn't be parsing HTML

'A known misconception about <meta http-equiv="Content-Type">  is that meta element is intended to be interpreted directly by a browser, like an ordinary HTML tag. According to WWW Consortium, it helps HTTP server[1]  to generate some headers when it serves the document.'
that said, it's a wiki page... it could easily be incorrect :)
I assume that was the original intention, hence it being called "http-equiv" and being equivalent to HTTP headers, but that's crazy and not how it works today
it does seem to gel with the description here as well though: http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/struct/global.html#edef-META
Indeed, but HTML4 is crazy and doesn't reflect reality either
heh :)
Imagine how fun it would be if every web server had its own HTML parser
Dashiva: how about if web servers sniffed the browser types and rewrote the HTML they were serving to be compatible? :D
Most web pages are generated dynamically and all the headers are output before any content, so it wouldn't even be possible to parse it and add headers
annevk: Can you elaborate why it was a deliberate decision btw? (complex ruby)
it's all just crazy anyway... encoding issues only exist because people were insane, and they turn sane people into insane people even now
asmodai, I believe that nobody really requested more than what IE already supported

workmad3: I don't think it's because people were insane - it was logical and sensible to invent all sorts of 8-bit encodings when computers rarely communicated with each other (and especially not internationally), to suit their particular needs
and then it was necessary to continue supporting them for legacy compatibility
which results in all these encoding issues
Philip`: maybe... I'll stick with my 'people are insane' view though, it justifies me cursing encodings more ;)
I'm not saying people aren't insane, just saying that there's other reasons for this situation :-)
annevk: ah ok

and insanity seems a reasonable explanation for why people continue to expose themselves to encoding issues even if they can avoid it (like when inventing new formats and languages), instead of sticking with Unicode internally and UTF-8 externally and not having to worry about it
annevk: I now feel like a proxy XD
pretty sure this was already discussed before with Richard
annevk: could be, at least I pointed it out to him now, I'm sure he'll get in contact
annevk: Thanks :)
np
anybody remember what as the rationale for not making the <rb> element conforming?
just for simplification?
if there is existing content that uses <rb> and that works as expected in IE, it would seem counter-productive to make such content invalid in HTML5
MikeSmith: I believe it's not supported in IE
(or it's no more supported than the <thisdoesnotexist> tag)
Philip`: OK
I guess the issue is that IE does not object to it
It's used sometimes but not always in existing content
I see
http://philip.html5.org/demos/html/ruby/wild-examples.html
looks now
I'd guess the reason for excluding is simplification - there's no point requiring people to do something that's unnecessary, and making it optional is adding needless complexity for authors
Philip`: I see
though I don't see any explicit rationale in the mailing lists, other than stating it's unnecessary and IE doesn't support it
Also it doesn't seem a very widely used feature so it doesn't hurt too much to make current uses non-conforming
that's always a judgement call, I guess
(Apparently I saw it on 0.3% of .jp sites in dmoz.org)

It's nowhere near as numerically significant as making e.g.
conforming

I see enough instances of <rb> in that sample at least that I am inclined to think that by prohibiting we are going to risk frustrating and confuseing a significant number sites that are already using it
and people still argued for keeping the syntax simpler in that case

MikeSmith: I expect confusion could be alleviated by validators printing a message saying "the <rb> tag is unnecessary and not permitted in HTML5 - remove the tags and your page will work just fine" rather than just "invalid element <rb>"
Philip`: yeah, that we can do
and our contract is with users is not that we are guaranteeing that everything that was valid in HTML4 or XHTML1 will continue to be valid in HTML5
MikeSmithX: .3% iirc is almost as low as the number of pages that use <image>, and we're not making _that_ conforming :-P
Hixie: if i wanted to write up a proposal for something, is http://dev.w3.org/html5/status/issue-status.html a good place to look at examples of how people have structured other proposals?
knowtheory: you should look here: <http://dev.w3.org/html5/decision-policy/decision-policy.html>
knowtheory: no, not really
knowtheory: if you want to propose something, best thing to do is to e-mail whatwg with a description of the problem you want to solve
imho
okay, thanks guys
Woohoo, today we're putting the new HTML5 stuff into the product.
knowtheory: the Change Proposal structure is only needed if something has been escalated, not for an initial informal proposal
othermaciej: okay :)
i've signed up to the whatwg list, so i'll post there if that's appropriate?
knowtheory: that is one of the appropriate places you can send feedback, yes
(it's one of the places i guarantee a reply eventually, too)
(the other option is the bugzilla system in the html working group)
s/option/place/
AryehGregor: yt?
or sicking
i'm looking at the empty attribute thread
which one?
the one talking about not fetching things for <Script src="">, etc
ah
thanks Hixie
Hixie: what about it?
if we make <script src=""> not fetch anything, should we also make it non-conforming?
and does that mean <script src=""> and <script src=" "> would be different from each other?
Hixie: i don't feel strongly on conforming vs. non-conforming
(<script src=" "> is non-conforming currently)
Hixie: is whitespace generally trimmed from these attributes?
(but it does result in a fetch, which would make it different)
well when resolving the url it is
Hixie: i.e. what does " " do currently?
not sure what you mean by "generally"
" " resolves to the base URL
do CSS Animations actually have a formal relationship to the HTML5 spec?  Or is it a detail of browser implementation, that CSS Animations would be included w/ HTML5?
Hixie: why does it resolve to the baseurl?
knowtheory: CSS animations are part of CSS, nothing to do with HTML
Hixie: wouldn't it convert to "%20" which is appended to the base?
sicking: spaces get trimmed first
Hixie: cool, just wanted to make sure i wasn't like way off base.
Hixie: ah, for relative urls? Or for all values of the attribute?
i'm loathe to make "" invalid everywhere given that it's a valid URL, but making it invalid only in some places is a bit weird...
all values
ponders
the "web addresses" stuff, assuming larry gets around to fixing it properly, trims spaces before resolving urls
seems like making foo invalid is a bit weird
Hixie: ok, from an implementation point of view, i'd prefer to just tread "" special. I.e. "" != " ". The former does nothing, the latter fetches the base url
but making <script src=""> valid but not do anything is also weird...
oh i agree that "" should be special, not in any way suggesting we make " " be handled differently
it's the conformance aspects of this i'm struggling with
Hixie: on the validity issue i don't feel strongly. I agree both options are weird in different ways
Hixie: one argument is that it might actually be convenient for authors to be able to use <script src="">
if we make "" invalid for external-resource <link>s, <link rel="stylesheet index" href=""> would be simultaneously valid and invalid, which is confusing as all hell
but if we make it valid, then <link rel=stylesheet href=""> would be valid but would not have the effect it should have given the url ""
Hixie: as to avoid having to do <%if ($bar) {%><script src="<%$bar%>"></script><%}%>
Hixie: yeah, i agree with your argument too
Hixie: politically it might be easier to make it invalid
i'm not worried about the politics
really? document validity tends to be more political than implementation conformance
it's the usability of the language i'm worried about
then i would say don't make it invalid
to avoid forcing authors to use the complex syntax above
having <link rel="stylesheet index" href=""> create just one link but <link rel="stylesheet index" href="#"> create two is very confusing
imhio
imho, even
though, i guess you could also argue that <script src=""> is likely a bug, and thus we'd help people by making it invalid so that the validator highlights the bug
that was the argument for making it not fetch anything in the first palce
place
that it was always a bug
true
ok, make it invalid then :)
is foo always a bug? maybe i should just make all empty URLs invalid
good question
having some be invalid and some not is very poor form
well.. i don't think there are any good solutions here
so we'll have to pick one bad solution
if we're picking bad solutions, it seems like making "" actually fetch the local page is the least bad solution from a usability perspective
why?
it makes the language self-consistent and predictable
we could say that if you refer to the local page that the UA must use the cached copy always
that seems like picking language purity over author friendlyness
"purity"?
it's picking author friendliness over server load friendliness
authors are generally in charge of server load. so the distinction doesn't make sense IMHO
if we say that if you refer to the local page that the UA must use the cached copy always, it doesn't even affect the load, which would be good
i.e. you'd be hurting the same guy as you're helping
granted
and probably hurting him more than helping
but if we use the cache we're not hurting at all
while still being predictable
there isn't always a cache around
well, in those cases we can hurt, i guess
there usually is
that doesn't seem to be true for
given that many browsers gave that special treatment
what isn't true?
that there is a cached copy around
i don't see why the browser behaviour indicates that one way or the other
it's just easier to implement "do nothing" than "fetch from the cache and then do nothing because HTML isn't an image format"
browsers implemented an exception because there was a detectable difference
by "browsers" you mean FF and Opera
all the other browsers fetch the image, according to the data collected in this thread
ah, thought it was more
in fact it's one of the few cases where IE does fetch the URL -- most of hte time it doesn't if it's ""
i still don't see how we're helping anyone by saying it should be fetched from cache
also, how is "should fetch from cache" different than not saying so? No browsers that i know of fetch from the network for the heck of it
well if fetching from the cache doesn't reduce the load, it's not clear to me why there's a problem here
so staying silent on the issue would result in the same browser behavior as far as i can see
huh?
fetching from the cache would reduce the load

right now, many browsers fetch something in these "" cases. I'm saying we should make it not fetch anything new but just use the available data instead. That seems like it would reduce the load, which is the stated problem.
but obviously at least firefox, opera and yahoo felt that the cache didn't reduce the load enough
Why would any author want to use empty src/href? That does not look sane to me :)
i dunno about "obviously"
firefox and opera obviously since they implemented it
yahoo in general i agree. This guy from yahoo obviously since he spent a lot of time figuring this out while developing the site
i think you're drawing conclusions from the data that aren't warranted -- e.g. opera's behaviour could be a random bug.
anyway, let's start from the beginning
the problem is that authors say src="", data="", etc, but don't mean to
yet they (presumably) say <a href=""> and _do_ mean to
we ideally would want to catch the errors but not flag the intentional cases
we ideally would want to not fetch data from the network for the error cases
we have certain language features where a single href="" can be in both situations at the same time, namely <link rel="stylesheet index" href="">
practically speaking though, when would that markup ever make sense?
given that i can't think of a case when it would, I don't care very much what the spec says about it
(i only care enough that i don't want to write a bunch of code to handle it, as that is effectively dead code)
<link rel="prefetch next" href=""> might, especially with scripting involved
neither "prefetch" or "next" is on the list of suggested changes though, is it?
"prefetch" is
it's an external resource link
true
and who knows what future external resource links might be invented
ok, so what is your point?
no point, i was just describing the problem
for daedb_'s benefit
it seems to me that everyone in that thread agreed on what UA behavior should be
so IMHO we should spec that behavior
there's also the mildly interesting case of (XML)
Hixie: <https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=30303>, if you want more opinions on the topic
the question of conformance has not been treated though
i don't have a strong opinion on that
though I think that in general things that are extremely likely to be bugs should be non-conforming
ap: reading...
as a rule of thumb
i guess we could make <a href="" rel=next> valid but <link href="" rel=next> invalid
and most authors wouldn't run into it
Hixie: sounds ok to me
should <script src=""></script> fire onload or onerror or neither?
and if an event is fired, should it be fired synchronously or asynchronously when parsing?
Hixie: i'd say fire onerror. To keep the consistency that onload or onerror is always fired
Hixie: and fire asynch, to keep that consistency that all events are async
IMHO
events with <script> aren't always async
e.g. <script>document.write('<script onload="alert(1)">alert(0)<\/script>');alert(2);</script> per spec
mind you either firefox nor safari fire that event at all as far as i can tell
actually no browser seems to
huh
spec bug?
unclear
i think firing onload in that case was an intentional addition
not sure about the sync vs async
ok i made it async in the internal case
should <embed type="application/plugin" src=""> instantiate the plugin based on the type="" attribute, or not at all?
i'll follow <object> and make <embed src=""> do nothing
er, <embed src="" type="..."> that is
